subject: Re: [junit] idiom for overriding tearDown()
msgSnippet: ... Not really. That super.tearDown() may remove resources that you need to do your own teardown. For example, it make close a database connection before you
messageBody:
On Thu, 22 Apr 2004, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> > protected void tearDown() throws Exception
> > {
> > super.tearDown();
> > // tear down your fixture here
> > }
>
> I would invert those, doing my own tear down first, just to make it the
> inverse of setUp(), but that's largely an arbitrary choice.

Not really. That super.tearDown() may remove resources that you need to
do your own teardown. For example, it make close a database connection
before you can remove test data you'd inserted.

I can see situations where you might want to do some work before
super.setUp() or after super.tearDown(), but those would be somewhat
odd, and might merit a bit of design review to see if there's a better
way to do it.

cjs
